texts.definition: Resources in games that are created simply by the passing of game time.
markups: <style="Definition">Resources in games that are created simply by the passing of game time.</style>

Players often manipulate various types of resources in games, and in many cases use up these through various actions. <style="CurrentLink">Regenerating Resources</style> are those which by themselves create more over time without any necessary actions performed by players.

Giantbomb has entries for the more specialized concepts Regenerating Ammo", "Regenerating Health", and "Shield Regeneration". Similarly, TV Tropes has entries for "Regenerating Health", "Regenerating Mana", and "Regenerating Shield.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Board%20Games">Board Games</link></style> that let players place "workers" to take actions, e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Agricola">Agricola</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dominant%20Species">Dominant Species</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Lords%20of%20Waterdeep">Lords of Waterdeep</link></style>, only provide players with a limited number of actions they can do every round. However, since players get these workers back at the end of the round they are a form of <style="CurrentLink">Regenerating Resources</style>. Money is another common form of <style="CurrentLink">Regenerating Resources</style> in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Board%20Games">Board Games</link></style>, players typically receive them in the beginning of a round. Although this is typically affected by which investments players have done, it can still be regarded as <style="CurrentLink">Regenerating Resources</style> when one does not have to use any other <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> to receive the money.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Roguelikes">Roguelikes</link></style>, i.e. games such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Angband">Angband</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Rogue">Rogue</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Diablo%20series">Diablo series</link></style>, lets the health and mana of players' character replenish over times. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Computer-based%20Roleplaying%20Games">Computer-based Roleplaying Games</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Arcanum:%20Of%20Steamworks%20and%20Magick%20Obscura">Arcanum: Of Steamworks and Magick Obscura</link></style>, the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallout%20series">Fallout series</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Mass%20Effect%20series">Mass Effect series</link></style> have similar ways of letting character heal or rest over time.

Regenerating health has become more and more common in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:FPS%20Games">FPS Games</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Spec%20Ops:%20The%20Line">Spec Ops: The Line</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Wolfenstein:%20New%20World%20Order">Wolfenstein: New World Order</link></style>, and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Battlefield%20series">Battlefield</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Call%20of%20Duty%20series">Call of Duty</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Just%20Cause%20series">Just Cause</link></style>,  and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Halo%20series">Halo series</link></style> to mention a few, have varying mechanisms for this although for some of the game series this has been introduced later. The <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Halo%20series">Halo series</link></style> also have a similar system for regenerating force shields (and had this before it had health regeneration). Other <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Computer%20Games">Computer Games</link></style> with similar system include <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/World%20of%20Warcraft">World of Warcraft</link></style> and later versions in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Deus%20Ex%20series">Deus Ex</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Metal%20Gear%20Solid%20series">Metal Gear Sold</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Metroid%20series">Metroid</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Tomb%20Raider%20series">Tomb Raider series</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/FTL:%20Faster%20Than%20Light">FTL: Faster Than Light</link></style> has <style="CurrentLink">Regenerating Resources</style> in the form of power shields that grow stronger by time after being hit. The largest units in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Warhammer%2040K">Warhammer 40K</link></style>, e.g. Imperial Titans or Ork Gargants, also have power shields that have a certain likelihood to regain their strength each turn after being overloaded.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Puzzle%20Games">Puzzle Games</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Candy%20Crush%20Saga">Candy Crush Saga</link></style> and some versions of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Peggle">Peggle</link></style> have lives as <style="CurrentLink">Regenerating Resources</style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Regenerating Resources</style> is introduced in games as a way of making <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> into <style="Link"><link="renewable-resources">Renewable Resources</link></style> but only require time to pass for this to happen. They can be necessary in <style="Link"><link="persistent-game-worlds">Persistent Game Worlds</link></style> where players would otherwise completely depleted the <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Regenerating Resources</style> are quite often limited by <style="Link"><link="resource-caps">Resource Caps</link></style> to avoid very large amounts of <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> to build up over time as gameplay progresses.

Examples of common types of <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> that can need to be regenerated for gameplay to progress at a wanted pace include <style="Link"><link="ammunition">Ammunition</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="budgeted-action-points">Budgeted Action Points</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Energy">Energy</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="health">Health</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Money">Money</link></style>. The rate at which <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> regenerate can be used to fine-tune gameplay or offer choices and actions; <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Income">Income</link></style> is for example one way of regulating how <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Money">Money</link></style> can work as a <style="CurrentLink">Regenerating Resource</style>. <style="Link"><link="lives">Lives</link></style> are <style="CurrentLink">Regenerating Resources</style> in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Puzzle%20Games">Puzzle Games</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Candy%20Crush%20Saga">Candy Crush Saga</link></style> and some versions of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Peggle">Peggle</link></style>.
<style="CurrentLink">Regenerating Resources</style> can, depending on their thematic nature, put strains on a <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Regenerating Resources</style> make <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> into a form of <style="Link"><link="renewable-resources">Renewable Resources</link></style> through <style="Link"><link="game-element-insertion">Game Element Insertion</link></style>. They provide one half of the mechanisms needed to create <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Faucet/Drain">Faucet/Drain</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Faucet/Sink">Faucet/Sink</link></style> systems, the other some form of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Game%20Element%20Removal">Game Element Removal</link></style>. When used together with <style="Link"><link="resource-caps">Resource Caps</link></style>, <style="CurrentLink">Regenerating Resources</style> work to ensure that there is a steady supply of <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> but still making them into <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Limited%20Resources">Limited Resources</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Regenerating Resources</style> in <style="Link"><link="persistent-game-worlds">Persistent Game Worlds</link></style> often result in <style="Link"><link="encouraged-return-visits">Encouraged Return Visits</link></style> because players may need certain <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> and know they will be available at a certain point in the future; one example of such as <style="Link"><link="resources">Resource</link></style> is <style="Link"><link="budgeted-action-points">Budgeted Action Points</link></style> - players can simply not perform any more actions until after a certain period of time has passed. This typically makes games using <style="CurrentLink">Regenerating Resources</style> on <style="Link"><link="budgeted-action-points">Budgeted Action Points</link></style> into <style="Link"><link="tick-based-games">Tick-Based Games</link></style>, as does its application on or <style="Link"><link="lives">Lives</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Regenerating Resources</style> as a pattern works directly against <style="Link"><link="non-renewable-resources">Non-Renewable Resources</link></style>. By doing so, it also works against <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Limited%20Resources">Limited Resources</link></style> if time is not an issue and this also make the pattern work against <style="Link"><link="resource-competition">Resource Competition</link></style>. Further, as the pattern does explicitly not one type of <style="Link"><link="resources">Resource</link></style> to create another, it breaks the requirement of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Closed%20Economies">Closed Economies</link></style>.
